  <div id="content">
    <div class="marginator">
                  <div class="columns main-columns">
        <h1 class="article-title  with-tabs">Recent Honors Theses</h1>                        <div id="body-content" class="second-column column main-column">
                                                  <div class="clear-block"> 
<article id="node-256" class="main-article node">








  <div class="content">
        <h2>2017 (Honors = 13)</h2>
<p>Victor Bramble (Track 1) <span class="small">&nbsp;Recipient&nbsp;of the&nbsp;</span><span><span class="small">Kenneth Baker ‘69 Memorial Honors Prize &nbsp;</span><br /></span>"Making Black Lives Matter: On the Circulation of Images of Black Death On Social Media" &nbsp;<span><br /></span><span>Thesis Advisor: Ariella Azoulay<br /></span><span>Reader: Barrymore Bogues</span></p>
<p>Nathaniel Burke (Track 2)<br />"Artificial"<br />Thesis Advisor: Anthony Cokes<br />Reader: Lynne Joyrich</p>
<p>Phoebe Gallo (Track 2)<br /><span>“The Politics of Ambiguity: An Exploration of Contemporary Turkish Networks”<br />Thesis Advisor: Lynne Joyrich<br />Reader: Wendy Chun</span></p>
<p>Devika Girish (Track 1) &nbsp;<span class="small">Recipient&nbsp;of the&nbsp;</span><span><span class="small">Kenneth Baker ‘69 Memorial Honors Prize</span></span><br /><span>“The Indian Neo-Wave: Essays on Independent Cinema in Neoliberal India”<br />Thesis Advisor: Philip Rosen<br />Reader: Vangelis Calotychos</span></p>
<p><span>Elizabeth Lippman (Track 2)<br /></span><span>"Broaden the Frame”<br />Advisor: Kelly Colvin<br />Reader: Leslie Thornton</span></p>
<p><span>Alec Mapes-Frances (Track 1)<br /></span><span>“Reading Machines: Ambient Writing and the Poetics of Atmospheric Media”<br />Thesis Advisor: Timothy Bewes<br />Reader: Diego Semerene<br /><br />Cole Moore (Track 2) &nbsp;<span class="small">Recipient&nbsp;of the&nbsp;</span><span><span class="small">Kenneth Baker ‘69 Memorial Honors Prize</span></span><br /></span><span>“Warp and Weft”<br />Thesis Advisor: Anthony Cokes<br />Reader: Joan Copjec</span></p>
<p><span>Frida Perez (Track 2)<br /></span><span>"Money”<br />Thesis Advisor: Theodore Bogosian<br />Reader: Bonnie Honig</span></p>
<p><span>Carly Risman (Track 2)<br /><span>“Please Record Your Message”<br />Thesis Advisor: Theodore Bogosian<br />Reader: Diego Semerene</span></span></p>
<p><span><span>Sophie Schwartz (Track 2)<br />"We Do the Rest"<br /></span></span><span>Thesis Advisor: Douglas Nickel<br /></span><span>Reader: Ariella Azoulay</span></p>
<p><span>Marcus Sudac (Track 2)<br />"Into Nowhere"<br />Thesis Advisor: Leslie Thornton<br />Reader: Anthony Cokes</span></p>
<p><span>Ellen Taylor (Track 1)<br /></span><span>“Furiously Inhabit These Sumptuous Bodies”<br /></span><span>Thesis Advisor: Philip Rosen<br /></span><span>Reader: Carole Maso<br /></span></p>
<p><span>Sienna Vann (Track 2)<br />"Satellite"<br />Thesis Advisor: Leslie Thornton<br />Reader: Anthony Cokes</span></p>
<h2>2016 (Honors = 8)</h2>
<p>Maria Paz Almenara (Track 1)  &nbsp;<span class="small">Recipient&nbsp;of the&nbsp;</span><span><span class="small">Kenneth Baker ‘69 Memorial Honors Prize</span></span><br />"Yuyanapaq: Photographic accounts of spectacle and disappearance in Peru, 1980-2000 <br />Thesis Advisor: Ariella Azoulay&nbsp; <br />Reader: Esther Whitfield</p>
<p>Pom Sirada Bunsermvicha (Track 2) <br />WRITTEN COMPONENT: "Capturing Reality, Creating Truth" <br />FILM: "E-po, Grandma’s Little Sister"<br /> Thesis Advisor: Joan Copjec <br />Reader: Leslie Thornton</p>
<p>Sebastian William Rider Clark (Track 2)<br /><span> "Updating Modernity in Chandigarh: Toward an Understanding of Form, Information and Informality in Urban Politics" <br />Thesis Advisor: Wendy Chun <br />Reader: Jo Guldi</span></p>
<p><span>Elizabeth Lauren Davis (Track &nbsp;2) <br />"Wir funktionieren automatik Jetzt wollen wir tanzen mechanik: an Inquiry into the Politics of Electronic Music 1960-1991"<br /> Thesis Advisor: Zachary Sng <br />Reader: Gerud Koch</span></p>
<p>Jade Donaldson (Track 2) <br />"The Electric Moon Peony Farm<br />" Thesis Advisor: Leslie Thornton <br />Reader: Elisa Giardina Papa</p>
<p>Grant Anthony Meyer (Track 1) <br />"“Good” Copy, “Bad” Copy: Discourses of Copying Within Appropriation Art, Popular Music, and Media Piracy, and Their Significance for the Ownership of Culture" <br />Thesis Advisor: Anthony Cokes <br />Reader: Wendy Chun</p>
<p>Hannah Rachel Subotnick (Track 2) <br /><span class="small">Recipient&nbsp;of the&nbsp;</span><span><span class="small">Kenneth Baker ‘69 Memorial Honors Prize &nbsp;<br /></span></span>"Beheld" <br />Thesis Advisor: John Cayley <br />Reader: Betsey Biggs</p>
<p>Jane Catherine Tracy (Track 1) <br />"Animation and the Representation of Conflict in Documentary Cinema: The Wanted 18, Waltz with Bashir, and Why We Fight<br />" Thesis Advisor: Philip Rosen <br />Reader: Gertrud Koch&nbsp;</p>
<h2><span style="color:#2f2a20">2015 (Honors = 5)&nbsp;</span></h2>
<p>Marianne Abbott (Track 2) &nbsp;<span class="small">Recipient&nbsp;of the&nbsp;</span><span><span class="small">Kenneth Baker ‘69 Memorial Honors Prize</span></span><br />"The Celluloid Woman: Reversing Dehumanization in Cinematic Representations of Women"<br /><span>Thesis Advisor: Anthony Cokes</span><br /><span>Reader: Matthew Tierney</span></p>
<p>Daniel Fethke (Track 2)<br />"Seeing Through Drones: An Investigation into Constructed Autonomous Vision"<br />Thesis Advisor: Wendy Chun<br />Reader: Anthony Cokes</p>
<p>Roberto Gedeon (Track 2)<br />"Oh, Cornelia!"<br /><span>Thesis Advisor: Carole Maso</span><br /><span>Reader: :Leslie Thornton</span></p>
<p><span>&nbsp;</span>Elisa Leser (Track 2)<br />"The Book"<br /><span>Thesis Advisor: Anthony Cokes</span><br /><span>Reader: Leslie Thornton</span></p>
<p><span></span>Augustus Longer (Track 1)<br />"Framed"<br /><span>Thesis Advisor: Leslie Thornton</span><br /><span>Reader: Elisa Giardina Papa</span></p>
<h2>2014 (Honors = 4)</h2>
<p>Blake Beaver (Track 1)<br />"Queer Anachronism: Perverse Temporalities in the Hours and To the Friend Who Did Not Save My Life"<br /><span>Thesis Advisor: Ellen Rooney</span><br /><span>Reader: &nbsp;Jacques Khalip</span></p>
<p>Sarah Friedland (Track 2) &nbsp;<span class="small">Recipient&nbsp;of the&nbsp;</span><span><span class="small">Kenneth Baker ‘69 Memorial Honors Prize</span></span><br />"The Meaning of the Moves: Gestural Mythologies and the Generic Film"<br /><span>Thesis Advisor: Lynne Joyrich</span><br /><span>Reader: Spencer Julie Strandberg<br />3rd Reader: David Barker&nbsp;</span></p>
<p>Anna Muselmann (Track 2)<br />"Palimpsest: Re-Membering the Traces of Ghosts"<br /><span>Thesis Advisor: Ellen Rooney</span><br /><span>Reader: Spencer Brandon Shaw</span></p>
<p>Daniel Stump (Track 2)<br />"Chill Yourself: The Life and Times of Gnar Tapes"&nbsp;<br /><span>Thesis Advisor: Anthony Cokes</span><br /><span>Reader: Michael Siegel</span></p>
<h2>2013 (Honors = 11)</h2>
<p>Alexis Aurigemma (Track 2)<br />"The Seagull: Stage to Screen"<br />Thesis Advisor: Anthony Cokes<br />Reader: Spencer Golub</p>
<p>Travis Bogosian (Track 2) &nbsp;<span class="small">Recipient&nbsp;of the&nbsp;</span><span><span class="small">Kenneth Baker ‘69 Memorial Honors Prize</span></span><br />"Forget-Me-Not"<br />Thesis Advisor: Ted Bogoian <br />Reader: Leslie Thornton</p>
<p>Adam Davis (Track 1)<br />"Budgeting for Success: Interior Design, Real Estate, and the Competitive Domesticity of Reality TV"<br /><span>Thesis Advisor: Lynne Joyrich<br />Reader: Wendy Chun</span></p>
<p><span>John-Gabriel Gonzalez (Track 2)<br /></span><span>"BlunderF*ck"<br />Thesis Advisor: Leslie Thornton<br />Reader: Anthony Cokes<br /><br />Emma Janaskie (Track 1) <span class="small">Recipient&nbsp;of the&nbsp;</span><span><span class="small">Kenneth Baker ‘69 Memorial Honors Prize</span></span><br /></span><span>"The Constant State of Desire: Thinking the Sexual Specificity of the Abjected/Fluid Female body with Kristeva and Irigaray"<br />Thesis Advisor: Ellen Rooney<br /></span><span>Reader: Timothy Bewes</span></p>
<p><span>Jelena Jelusic (Track 1)<br />"Negociating Mediated Identities: Female Stars and Contradictions of Gender"<br />Thesis Advisor: Lynne Joyrich<br />Reader: Ellen Rooney</span></p>
<p><span>Hannah Levy (Track 2)<br />"The Rules" <br />Thesis Advisor: Leslie Thornton<br />Reader: Lynne Joyrich</span></p>
<p><span>Alyssa Migliori (Track 2)<br />"Finding Monk"<br />Thesis Advisor: Leslie Thornton<br />Reader: David Barker</span></p>
<p><span>Ariel Rodriguez (Track 2) &nbsp;<br /><span class="small">Recipient&nbsp;of the&nbsp;</span><span><span class="small">Kenneth Baker ‘69 Memorial Honors Prize</span></span><br />"Performance Script: For Audience Member<br />Thesis Advisor: Rebecca Schneider<br />Reader: Ellen Rooney</span></p>
<p><span>Rosemary Selig-Addiss (Track 1)<br />"Masked Encounters"<br />Thesis Advisor: Joshua Neves<br />Reader: Leslie Thornton</span></p>
<p><span>Jennifer Vincent (Track 2)<br />"Leave a False Name"<br />Thesis Advisor: Rebecca Schneider<br />Reader: Joshua Neves&nbsp;</span></p>
<h2>2012 (Honors = 8)</h2>
<p>Alexander Ashe (Track 2)<br />"Luanne"<br />Thesis Advisor: Michael Siegel<br />Reader: Anthony Cokes&nbsp;</p>
<p>Dia Barghouti (Track 2)<br />"Secrets of the Name Ibn-Sinana"<br />Thesis Advisor: Erik Ehn<br />Reader: Mark Tribe</p>
<p>Jordan Carter (Track 1) &nbsp;<span class="small">Recipient&nbsp;of the&nbsp;</span><span><span class="small">Kenneth Baker ‘69 Memorial Honors Prize</span></span><br />"A Virtual Process: Socially Engaged Art in the Context of Network Culture"<br />Thesis Advisor: Philip Rosen<br />Reader: Herve Vavel</p>
<p>Yeon Seung Hong (Track 2) &nbsp;<span class="small">Recipient&nbsp;of the&nbsp;</span><span><span class="small">Kenneth Baker ‘69 Memorial Honors Prize</span></span><br />"To Like a Work of Music in the Age of Digital Reproduction"<br />Thesis Advisor: Anthony Cokes<br />Reader: Wendy Chun</p>
<p>Andrew Lenoir (Track 2) &nbsp;<span class="small">Recipient&nbsp;of the&nbsp;</span><span><span class="small">Kenneth Baker ‘69 Memorial Honors Prize</span></span><br />"Dead Lies Dreaming: &nbsp;H.P. Lovecraft and the Other Side of Modernity"<br />Thesis Advisor: David Bering-Porter<br />Reader: Michal Oklot</p>
<p>Daniel Lopez-Goicochea (Track 2)<br />"Transplanted; A Photoethnography of abstract displacement and constructed localism"<br />Thesis Advisor: Theresa Ganz<br />Reader: Mark Tribe</p>
<p>Edward Myerberg (Track 2) &nbsp;<span class="small">Recipient&nbsp;of the&nbsp;</span><span><span class="small">Kenneth Baker ‘69 Memorial Honors Prize</span></span><br />"Layover &amp; Sunday Afternoon: A Film in Two Parts"<br />Thesis Advisor: Mar Tribe<br />Reader: Carole Maso</p>
<p>Tracy Szatan (Track 2)<br />"a m a s &nbsp;s"<br />Thesis Advisor: Anthony Cokes<br />Reader: Carole Maso&nbsp;</p>
<h2>2011 (Honors = 11)</h2>
<p>Evan Donahue (Track 2)<br />"The Man in the Mask: Artistic Practice at the Edge of Terror"<br />Thesis Advisor: Wendy Chun&nbsp;<br />Reader: Fred Moten, Duke University</p>
<p>Sean Feiner (Track 1) &nbsp;<span class="small">Recipient&nbsp;of the&nbsp;</span><span><span class="small">Kenneth Baker ‘69 Memorial Honors Prize</span></span><br />"The Discipline of Gaming: The Ethics and Design of Affective Labor"<br />Thesis Advisor: Wendy Chun&nbsp;<br />Reader: &nbsp;Ellen Rooney&nbsp;</p>
<p>Emily Fishman (Track 2) &nbsp;<span class="small">Recipient&nbsp;of the&nbsp;</span><span><span class="small">Kenneth Baker ‘69 Memorial Honors Prize</span></span><br />"Fashion and the Role of Personal History in the Construction of the Individual"<br />Thesis Advisor: Lynne Joyrich&nbsp;<br />Reader: Leslie Bostrom, Visual Art&nbsp;</p>
<p>Monica Garcia (Track 1)<br />"Human(e) Borders: Tracking Interventions in the U.S. Borderlands<br />Thesis Advisor: Wendy Chun&nbsp;<br />Reader: Philip Rosen and Barrymore Bogues, Africana Studies</p>
<p>Harrison Heller (Track 2)<br />"Virtuality, Warefare, and the Military-Entertainment Complex"<br />Thesis Advisor: Mark Tribe&nbsp;<br />Reader: Leslie Thornton&nbsp;</p>
<p>Ioana Jucan (Track 2) &nbsp;<span class="small">Recipient&nbsp;of the&nbsp;</span><span><span class="small">Kenneth Baker ‘69 Memorial Honors Prize</span></span><br />"Face-to-Face: Screening the Face in the Culture of the Interface"<br />Thesis Advisor: Wendy Chun&nbsp;<br />Reader: Mary Ann Doane&nbsp;</p>
<p>Jonathan Lee (Track 2)<br />"De-Vision"<br />Thesis Advisor: Leslie Thornton&nbsp;<br />Reader: Anthony Cokes&nbsp;</p>
<p>Jungmin Lee (Track 2)<br />"Modes of Exhibition as Mediated Space: Projection Installation as Spectatorial Frame<br />Thesis Advisor: Anthony Cokes&nbsp;<br />Reader: Herve Vanel, History of Art and Architecture&nbsp;</p>
<p>Liana Ogden (Semiotics-French) &nbsp;<span class="small">Recipient&nbsp;of the&nbsp;</span><span><span class="small">Kenneth Baker ‘69 Memorial Honors Prize &nbsp;</span></span>"Avisceral Animal: &nbsp;Projecting and Indexing Life in the Age of Bioethics<br />Thesis Advisor: Thangam Ravindranathan, French Studies&nbsp;<br />Reader: Mary Ann Doane&nbsp;</p>
<p>Farah Shaer (Track 2)<br />"F.R.E.D."<br />Thesis Advisor: Stephen Groening<br />Reader: Barret Hazeltine, Engineering&nbsp;</p>
<p>David Walker (Track 2)<br />"Psychiatrist"<br />Thesis Advisor: Anthony Cokes<br />Reader: Leslie Thornton&nbsp;</p>
<h2>2010 (Honors = 4)</h2>

<p>Alexandra Chemla (Track 2)<br />"Left to Chance"<br />Thesis Advisor: Mark Tribe&nbsp;<br />Reader: Richard Fishman, Visual Art&nbsp;</p>
<p>Samuel Ewenczyk (Track 1) &nbsp;<span class="small">Recipient&nbsp;of the&nbsp;</span><span><span class="small">Kenneth Baker ‘69 Memorial Honors Prize</span></span><br />"Representations of the Male Body in Contemporary Advertising Images"<br />Thesis Advisor: Mary Ann Doane&nbsp;<br />Reader: Wendy Chun&nbsp;</p>

<h2>2009 (Honors = 8)</h2>
<p>Megan Billman (Track 2)<br />"Adolescent Projectors"<br />Thesis Advisor: Paul Myoda, Visual Art&nbsp;<br />Reader: Micahel Udris&nbsp;</p>
<p>Megan Goetsch (Art-Semiotics)<br />"Exploding Glossy Images: Postmodernism in Art-Fashion Photography and the Case of Weird Beauty"<br />Thesis Advisor: &nbsp;Micahel Silverman&nbsp;<br />Reader: Douglas Nickel&nbsp;</p>
<p>Abraham Halpert (Art-Semiotics)<br />"After Birthright"&nbsp;<br />Thesis Advisor: Michael Udris&nbsp;<br />Reader: Leslie Thornton&nbsp;</p>

<p>Valeria Iavtouhovitsh (MCM)<br />"Hold Still"<br />Thesis Advisor: &nbsp;Micahel Silverman<br />Reader: Leslie Thornton&nbsp;</p>

<p>Sonya Mladenova (MCM-German)<br />"W.G. Sebald's Die Ausgewanderten: Human Consciousness as Photographic Plate"<br />Thesis Advisor: Zachary Sng, German Studies&nbsp;<br />Reader: Susan Bernstein, Comparative Literature &nbsp;</p>
<h2>2008 (Honors = 13)</h2>
<p>Meghan Boudreau (Art-Semiotics)<br />"Blue Pills and Blue Pens"<br />Thesis Advisor: Micahel Udris&nbsp;<br />Reader: Anthony Cokes&nbsp;</p>

        <div class="list">

	<div id="block-ultibanner-0" class="clear-block block block-ultibanner ">
	
		
		<div class="content">



	<!--div id="node-1078" class="ultibanner banner"-->
		<img  class="imagefield imagefield-field_ultibanner_image" width="940" height="300" alt="" src="https://www.brown.edu/academics/modern-culture-and-media/sites/brown.edu.academics.modern-culture-and-media/files/ultibanner/ursa_minor_robust_banner_image.jpg?1467310782" />	<!--/div-->

          <div class="banner-text">
				<h1><a href="/academics/modern-culture-and-media/" title=""><span class="site-title"></span></a></h1><div id="site-mission" class="mission banner-subtext"></div>			</div>
        </section>
	  
  <!-- Layout -->
  <div id="content">
    <div class="marginator">
                  <div class="columns main-columns">
        <h1 class="article-title  with-tabs">The Thesis</h1>                        <div id="body-content" class="second-column column main-column">
                                                  <div class="clear-block"> 
<article id="node-260" class="main-article node">








  <div class="content">
        <p>The final version of your thesis needs to be bound. <a href="http://www.brown.edu/Facilities/Metcalf_Copy_Center/other_binding.html">(See Metcalf Copy Center for binding options.)</a></p>
<p><span><span>Film and Video projects and documentation of other works should be submitted on a DVD, flash drive, etc.&nbsp;</span></span></p>
<h2>You need to submit THREE copies to:</h2>
<ol>
<li><span>Honors advisor (bound copy)<br /></span></li>
<li>2nd reader (ask if they require a bound copy)</li>
<li>Department (submit electronically to the Hay Library <a href="https://goo.gl/forms/TLwc2v392Es5oob03" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">https://goo.gl/forms/TLwc2v392Es5oob03</a><span>&nbsp;</span>&nbsp;and to MCM at <a href="mailto:MCM@brown.edu">MCM@brown.edu</a>)&nbsp;<br /><br />If your project is a paper, you can upload a PDF<span>.&nbsp;<br /></span>If your project is not a paper, or if you have accompanying supplementary materials/data/media (video files, audio,&nbsp;<span>photographs, images, spreadsheets,figures, tables, graphs, software etc.) you can also upload these files at the link below.&nbsp;<strong>&nbsp;</strong></span></li>
</ol>
<ol></ol>
<h2>Format of your thesis:</h2>
<ul>
<li><span>The format is determined by your project advisor. &nbsp;Overall requirements - neat in appearance and ample margins.</span><span>&nbsp;</span></li>
</ul>
  </div>

	
  <div class="clear-block">
    <div class="meta">


	    
		</div><!-- end .meta -->
	</div>

</article>
 </div>
                     </div>
        <!-- end .second-column -->

		<div class="content">



	<!--div id="node-1078" class="ultibanner banner"-->
		<img  class="imagefield imagefield-field_ultibanner_image" width="940" height="300" alt="" src="https://www.brown.edu/academics/modern-culture-and-media/sites/brown.edu.academics.modern-culture-and-media/files/ultibanner/ursa_minor_robust_banner_image.jpg?1467310782" />	<!--/div-->

          <div class="banner-text">
				<h1><a href="/academics/modern-culture-and-media/" title=""><span class="site-title"></span></a></h1><div id="site-mission" class="mission banner-subtext"></div>			</div>
        </section>
	  
  <!-- Layout -->
  <div id="content">
    <div class="marginator">
                  <div class="columns main-columns">
        <h1 class="article-title  with-tabs">The Thesis</h1>                        <div id="body-content" class="second-column column main-column">
                                                  <div class="clear-block"> 
<article id="node-260" class="main-article node">








  <div class="content">
        <p>The final version of your thesis needs to be bound. <a href="http://www.brown.edu/Facilities/Metcalf_Copy_Center/other_binding.html">(See Metcalf Copy Center for binding options.)</a></p>
<p><span><span>Film and Video projects and documentation of other works should be submitted on a DVD, flash drive, etc.&nbsp;</span></span></p>
<h2>You need to submit THREE copies to:</h2>
<ol>
<li><span>Honors advisor (bound copy)<br /></span></li>
<li>2nd reader (ask if they require a bound copy)</li>
<li>Department (submit electronically to the Hay Library <a href="https://goo.gl/forms/TLwc2v392Es5oob03" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">https://goo.gl/forms/TLwc2v392Es5oob03</a><span>&nbsp;</span>&nbsp;and to MCM at <a href="mailto:MCM@brown.edu">MCM@brown.edu</a>)&nbsp;<br /><br />If your project is a paper, you can upload a PDF<span>.&nbsp;<br /></span>If your project is not a paper, or if you have accompanying supplementary materials/data/media (video files, audio,&nbsp;<span>photographs, images, spreadsheets,figures, tables, graphs, software etc.) you can also upload these files at the link below.&nbsp;<strong>&nbsp;</strong></span></li>
</ol>
<ol></ol>
<h2>Format of your thesis:</h2>
<ul>
<li><span>The format is determined by your project advisor. &nbsp;Overall requirements - neat in appearance and ample margins.</span><span>&nbsp;</span></li>
</ul>
  </div>

	
  <div class="clear-block">
    <div class="meta">


	    
		</div><!-- end .meta -->
	</div>

</article>
 </div>
                     </div>

	<div class="block-views-contact_information-block_1 clear-block block block-views ">

      <div class="view-content">

          <div class="banner-text">
				<h1><a href="/academics/modern-culture-and-media/" title=""><span class="site-title"></span></a></h1><div id="site-mission" class="mission banner-subtext"></div>			</div>
        </section>
	  
  <!-- Layout -->
  <div id="content">
    <div class="marginator">
                  <div class="columns main-columns">
        <h1 class="article-title  with-tabs">The 5th Year Master’s Degree in Modern Culture and Media</h1>                        <div id="body-content" class="second-column column main-column">
                                                  <div class="clear-block"> 
<article id="node-193" class="main-article node">








  <div class="content">
        <h2>The 5<sup>th</sup> Year Master’s Degree in Modern Culture and Media</h2>
<p>The 5<sup>th</sup> Year Master’s Degree in Modern Culture and Media allows an MCM concentrator to continue at Brown for a master’s degree after completing the bachelor’s degree. Two courses taken as an undergraduate will be counted toward the master’s degree, leaving six courses to be taken in the postgraduate year and only six tuition units to be paid for the usual eight course degree. Students cannot transfer a graduate course taken at another school.<span>&nbsp;</span></p>
<h2>Integration of undergraduate and graduate coursework</h2>
<p><em>University regulations mandate that the student must take enough courses to earn each degree independently; that is, no courses may count towards both degrees</em><em>. </em>Because of this, the department requires that, by the end of the fourth year, the candidate must have taken two extra MCM courses over and above requirements for the MCM concentration. These extra courses must be appropriate for graduate credit (1000- or 2000-level MCM courses.)</p>
<p>The reason is the following. Eight courses are required for the M.A. in Modern Culture and Media. First-year graduate students normally take six courses, and this is what 5<sup>th</sup> Year Master’s students will do during their fifth year. Therefore, to meet the eight-course requirement for the fifth year, the department requires two applicable courses before the fifth year. Note: While, the two extra courses applying to the M.A. may not count towards an undergraduate concentration in MCM, they may still count towards the 30-course graduation requirement for the bachelor’s degree.</p>
<p>MCM concentrators considering applying to this program should consult with the Director of Graduate Studies as well as their undergraduate advisor about the two extra courses. In the fifth year, courses will be chosen in consultation with the Director of Graduate Studies, who will be the student’s advisor.<span>&nbsp;</span></p>
<h2>Applying to the program<span>&nbsp;</span></h2>
<p>A student must apply for the program no later than the second week of the final semester of undergraduate study. Admission must be approved by the Department of Modern Culture and Media and by the Graduate School. While a student must be enrolled as an active undergraduate student at the time of application, admission to the graduate program can be deferred for up to two years with approval of the program.<span>&nbsp;</span></p>
<p><strong>Requirements for Admission to the program: </strong>The applicant must be a concentrator in MCM with a 3.5 GPA in MCM courses.<span>&nbsp;</span></p>
<p><strong>Application deadline:</strong> &nbsp;A student must make application no later than the second week of his or her final semester of undergraduate study.<span>&nbsp;</span></p>
<p><strong>Submissions to the department:</strong> The applicant must write a letter to the Director of Graduate Studies informing the department in writing that she or he is applying to the 5<sup>th</sup> Year Master’s program in MCM. This letter should indicate MCM faculty with whom the applicant has worked. The applicant must also provide a writing sample of work done for an MCM class. The writing sample should be included with the letter.<span>&nbsp;</span></p>
<p><strong>Submissions to the Graduate School: </strong>In addition, the applicant must complete the <a href="https://www.applyweb.com/browng/index.ftl" rel="nofollow">online application</a> and the <a href="https://www.brown.edu/academics/gradschool/sites/brown.edu.gradschool/files/5thyearmastersSuppaApp.pdf">5th-Year Master’s Degree Application Supplement Form</a>. &nbsp;Both applications can be obtained from the <a href="https://www.brown.edu/academics/gradschool/">Graduate School website</a>. &nbsp;Two letters of recommendation are required.</p>
<h2>Requirements for the M.A. in the 5<sup>th</sup> Year Master’s Degree</h2>
<p><em>Coursework</em>: A total of 8 courses suitable for graduate credit (1000- or 2000- level, including production) and approved by the MCM Director of Graduate Studies. None of these may be courses that count towards the undergraduate degree. Among these eight courses, candidates are required to take at least one 2000-level MCM course in each of the following areas:<span>&nbsp;</span></p>
<ul>
<li>Theory<br /> (Normally fulfilled by one of the following: MCM2100, MCM2110, MCM2120.)<span>&nbsp;</span></li>
</ul>
<ul>
<li>&nbsp;Textual Analysis<br /> (Normally fulfilled by one of the following: MCM2300, MCM2310.)<span>&nbsp;</span></li>
</ul>
<ul>
<li>Historical/Cultural Locations<br /> (Normally fulfilled by one of the following: MCM2500, MCM2510.)</li>
</ul>
<p><em>90-minute Qualifying Review:&nbsp; A</em>dministered by the Graduate Committee upon completion of coursework. There is a description of the Qualifying Review for doctoral candidates in the department’s Graduate Student Handbook. The exam will be modified to make it suitable for a terminal M.A. candidate.&nbsp;</p>
  </div>

	
  <div class="clear-block">
    <div class="meta">


	    
		</div><!-- end .meta -->
	</div>

</article>

          <div class="banner-text">
				<h1><a href="/academics/modern-culture-and-media/" title=""><span class="site-title"></span></a></h1><div id="site-mission" class="mission banner-subtext"></div>			</div>
        </section>
	  
  <!-- Layout -->
  <div id="content">
    <div class="marginator">
                  <div class="columns main-columns">
        <h1 class="article-title  with-tabs">The 5th Year Master’s Degree in Modern Culture and Media</h1>                        <div id="body-content" class="second-column column main-column">
                                                  <div class="clear-block"> 
<article id="node-193" class="main-article node">








  <div class="content">
        <h2>The 5<sup>th</sup> Year Master’s Degree in Modern Culture and Media</h2>
<p>The 5<sup>th</sup> Year Master’s Degree in Modern Culture and Media allows an MCM concentrator to continue at Brown for a master’s degree after completing the bachelor’s degree. Two courses taken as an undergraduate will be counted toward the master’s degree, leaving six courses to be taken in the postgraduate year and only six tuition units to be paid for the usual eight course degree. Students cannot transfer a graduate course taken at another school.<span>&nbsp;</span></p>
<h2>Integration of undergraduate and graduate coursework</h2>
<p><em>University regulations mandate that the student must take enough courses to earn each degree independently; that is, no courses may count towards both degrees</em><em>. </em>Because of this, the department requires that, by the end of the fourth year, the candidate must have taken two extra MCM courses over and above requirements for the MCM concentration. These extra courses must be appropriate for graduate credit (1000- or 2000-level MCM courses.)</p>
<p>The reason is the following. Eight courses are required for the M.A. in Modern Culture and Media. First-year graduate students normally take six courses, and this is what 5<sup>th</sup> Year Master’s students will do during their fifth year. Therefore, to meet the eight-course requirement for the fifth year, the department requires two applicable courses before the fifth year. Note: While, the two extra courses applying to the M.A. may not count towards an undergraduate concentration in MCM, they may still count towards the 30-course graduation requirement for the bachelor’s degree.</p>
<p>MCM concentrators considering applying to this program should consult with the Director of Graduate Studies as well as their undergraduate advisor about the two extra courses. In the fifth year, courses will be chosen in consultation with the Director of Graduate Studies, who will be the student’s advisor.<span>&nbsp;</span></p>
<h2>Applying to the program<span>&nbsp;</span></h2>
<p>A student must apply for the program no later than the second week of the final semester of undergraduate study. Admission must be approved by the Department of Modern Culture and Media and by the Graduate School. While a student must be enrolled as an active undergraduate student at the time of application, admission to the graduate program can be deferred for up to two years with approval of the program.<span>&nbsp;</span></p>
<p><strong>Requirements for Admission to the program: </strong>The applicant must be a concentrator in MCM with a 3.5 GPA in MCM courses.<span>&nbsp;</span></p>
<p><strong>Application deadline:</strong> &nbsp;A student must make application no later than the second week of his or her final semester of undergraduate study.<span>&nbsp;</span></p>
<p><strong>Submissions to the department:</strong> The applicant must write a letter to the Director of Graduate Studies informing the department in writing that she or he is applying to the 5<sup>th</sup> Year Master’s program in MCM. This letter should indicate MCM faculty with whom the applicant has worked. The applicant must also provide a writing sample of work done for an MCM class. The writing sample should be included with the letter.<span>&nbsp;</span></p>
<p><strong>Submissions to the Graduate School: </strong>In addition, the applicant must complete the <a href="https://www.applyweb.com/browng/index.ftl" rel="nofollow">online application</a> and the <a href="https://www.brown.edu/academics/gradschool/sites/brown.edu.gradschool/files/5thyearmastersSuppaApp.pdf">5th-Year Master’s Degree Application Supplement Form</a>. &nbsp;Both applications can be obtained from the <a href="https://www.brown.edu/academics/gradschool/">Graduate School website</a>. &nbsp;Two letters of recommendation are required.</p>
<h2>Requirements for the M.A. in the 5<sup>th</sup> Year Master’s Degree</h2>
<p><em>Coursework</em>: A total of 8 courses suitable for graduate credit (1000- or 2000- level, including production) and approved by the MCM Director of Graduate Studies. None of these may be courses that count towards the undergraduate degree. Among these eight courses, candidates are required to take at least one 2000-level MCM course in each of the following areas:<span>&nbsp;</span></p>
<ul>
<li>Theory<br /> (Normally fulfilled by one of the following: MCM2100, MCM2110, MCM2120.)<span>&nbsp;</span></li>
</ul>
<ul>
<li>&nbsp;Textual Analysis<br /> (Normally fulfilled by one of the following: MCM2300, MCM2310.)<span>&nbsp;</span></li>
</ul>
<ul>
<li>Historical/Cultural Locations<br /> (Normally fulfilled by one of the following: MCM2500, MCM2510.)</li>
</ul>
<p><em>90-minute Qualifying Review:&nbsp; A</em>dministered by the Graduate Committee upon completion of coursework. There is a description of the Qualifying Review for doctoral candidates in the department’s Graduate Student Handbook. The exam will be modified to make it suitable for a terminal M.A. candidate.&nbsp;</p>
  </div>

	
  <div class="clear-block">
    <div class="meta">


	    
		</div><!-- end .meta -->
	</div>

</article>
 </div>
                     </div>
        <!-- end .second-column -->

  <div class="marginator">
  <nav id="tablet-nav" class="tmenu">
        <div>
        <h5>Find:</h5>
       	<ul>
        <li class="first"><a href="http://www.brown.edu/a-to-z" rel="nofollow">A to Z Index</a></li>
        <li class="last"><a href="http://directory.brown.edu" rel="nofollow">People Directory</a></li>

				<h1><a href="/academics/modern-culture-and-media/" title=""><span class="site-title"></span></a></h1><div id="site-mission" class="mission banner-subtext"></div>			</div>

  <div id="content">
    <div class="marginator">
                  <div class="columns main-columns">
        <h1 class="article-title  with-tabs">MCM DUG</h1>                        <div id="body-content" class="second-column column main-column">
                                                  <div class="clear-block"> 
<article id="node-194" class="main-article node">








  <div class="content">
        <h2>ACTIVE DUG MEMBERS</h2>
<p>The DUG (Deparment Undergraduate Group) MCM concentrators meeting together every once in awhile in order to plan fun and exciting events that build community among concentrators. They organize student installations and film shows with receptions and more. Come to a meeting and give your input. Email&nbsp;for more information at:&nbsp;mcm@brown.edu</p>
<p><strong>2017-2018 DUG members:</strong>&nbsp; Keri Brooks '18, Jason Hebert '19, Ana Marx '18, Miles Taylor '18, Jina Yoon '18</p>
<p><span class="highlight">Follow the DUG on </span><a class="highlight" href="https://www.facebook.com/groups/531998393813655/" rel="nofollow">Facebook</a><br />join the mcm facebook group! a casual space for students @ brown to share mcm-related ideas, exciting events and info, ~quality content~ and more.you don't have to be a concentrator to join; anyone interested in mcm is more than welcome :-) (you will need to login with your brown email)</p>
<hr />
<p><br /><a href="https://www.brown.edu/academics/modern-culture-and-media/2017-2018-dug-events">CURRENT DUG EVENTS (2017-2018)</a></p>
<hr />
<p><strong style="color:#2f2a20">DUG members&nbsp;</strong></p>
<p><a href="https://www.brown.edu/academics/modern-culture-and-media/mcm-dug-members-2017-2018">MCM DUG Members 2017-2018</a><a href="https://www.brown.edu/academics/modern-culture-and-media/mcm-dug-members-2016-2017"><br />MCM DUG members 2016-2017</a><a href="http://www.brown.edu/academics/modern-culture-and-media/mcm-dug-members-2015-2016"><br />MCM DUG members 2015-2016<br /></a><a href="http://www.brown.edu/academics/modern-culture-and-media/mcm-dug-members-2014-2015">MCM DUG members 2014-205<br /></a><a href="http://www.brown.edu/academics/modern-culture-and-media/mcm-dug-members-2013-2014">MCM DUG members 2013-2014<br /></a><a href="http://www.brown.edu/academics/modern-culture-and-media/mcm-dug-members-2012-2013">MCM DUG members 2012-2013<br /></a><a href="http://www.brown.edu/academics/modern-culture-and-media/mcm-dug-members-2011-2012">MCM DUG members 2011-2012<br /></a><a href="http://www.brown.edu/academics/modern-culture-and-media/dug-members-2010-2011">MCM DUG members 2010-2011</a></p>
<p><strong style="color:#2f2a20"> </strong></p>
<hr />
<h4><strong style="color:#2f2a20">Past DUG events<br />&nbsp;</strong></h4>
<p><a href="https://www.brown.edu/academics/modern-culture-and-media/2016-2017-dug-events">2016-2017 DUG events</a><br /><a href="http://www.brown.edu/academics/modern-culture-and-media/2015-2016-dug-events">2015-2016 DUG events</a><br /><a href="http://www.brown.edu/academics/modern-culture-and-media/2014-2015-dug-events">2014-2015 DUG events<br /></a><a href="http://www.brown.edu/academics/modern-culture-and-media/2013-2014-dug-events">2013-2014 DUG events<br /></a><a href="http://www.brown.edu/academics/modern-culture-and-media/2012-2013-dug-events">2012-2013 DUG events<br /></a><a href="http://brown.edu/academics/modern-culture-and-media/2011-2012-dug-events" target="_blank">2011-2012 DUG events<br /></a><a href="http://brown.edu/academics/modern-culture-and-media/2010-2011-dug-events" target="_blank">2010-2011 DUG events<br /></a><a href="http://brown.edu/academics/modern-culture-and-media/2009-2010-dug-events" target="_blank">2009-2010 DUG events<br /></a><a href="http://brown.edu/academics/modern-culture-and-media/2008-2009-dug-events" target="_blank">2008-2009 DUG Events<br /></a><a href="http://brown.edu/academics/modern-culture-and-media/earlier-dug-events" target="_blank">Earlier DUG events </a></p>
<hr />
<p><a href="http://brown.edu/academics/modern-culture-and-media/earlier-dug-events" target="_blank"> </a></p>
<h4><a href="/academics/modern-culture-and-media/past-events/senior-show" title="Senior Show" rel="nofollow">MCM Student Senior Show&nbsp;</a></h4>

		<div class="content"><div class="view view-contact-information view-id-contact_information view-display-id-block_1 view-dom-id-1">
    
  
  
      <div class="view-content">
        <div class="views-row views-row-1 views-row-odd views-row-first views-row-last">
    <div class="vcard">
	<div class="adr">
		<div class="org">
			<div class="organization-unit">Modern Culture and Media</div>
 <div class="organization-name">Brown University</div>
		</div>
			<div class="post-office-box">Box 1957</div>
<div class="street-address">155 George Street</div>
		<span class="locality">Providence</span>, <abbr class="region" title="Rhode Island">RI</abbr> <span class="postal-code">02912</span>
	</div>
	<div class="tel"><span class="type">Phone</span> <span class="value">401-863-2853</span></div>
	<div class="tel"><span class="type">Fax</span> <span class="value">401-863-2158</span></div>
	<div><a class="email" href="mailto:mcm@brown.edu">mcm@brown.edu</a></div>

      <div id="brown-brand">
        <div class="marginator">
          <h1><a href="http://www.brown.edu" accesskey="1" title="Brown University Homepage"><img src="/academics/modern-culture-and-media/sites/all/themes/pawtucket/img/brown-logo.png" alt="Brown University Seal" /><span>Brown University</span></a></h1>
            <section id="mobile-navigation">
  <div class="marginator">
  <nav id="mobile-nav" class="mmenu">     
		
        <div class="item-list">		
                             	<h3 class="current-site"><a href="">Modern Culture and Media</a></h3>
            
      
        <div class="list">
        
	
	<div class="block-menu-primary-links clear-block block block-menu ">
	
		
		<div class="content"><ul class="menu"><li class="leaf first menu-home"><a href="/academics/modern-culture-and-media/welcome-department-modern-culture-and-media" title="Home">Home</a></li>

		<img  class="imagefield imagefield-field_ultibanner_image" width="940" height="300" alt="" src="https://www.brown.edu/academics/modern-culture-and-media/sites/brown.edu.academics.modern-culture-and-media/files/ultibanner/ursa_minor_robust_banner_image.jpg?1467310782" />	<!--/div-->

          <div class="banner-text">
				<h1><a href="/academics/modern-culture-and-media/" title=""><span class="site-title"></span></a></h1><div id="site-mission" class="mission banner-subtext"></div>			</div>
        </section>
	  
  <!-- Layout -->
  <div id="content">
    <div class="marginator">
                  <div class="columns main-columns">
        <h1 class="article-title  with-tabs">Track I</h1>                        <div id="body-content" class="second-column column main-column">
                                                  <div class="clear-block"> 
<article id="node-189" class="main-article node">








  <div class="content">
        <p>Track I concentrators may choose to study a particular historical moment, a medium, or a mode of textual production, in combination with theoretical studies that examine the categories of cultural analysis: for example, the distinction between high and low culture. Examples of areas of interest include but are not limited to film, gender/sexuality, digital media, television, post-coloniality, the novel, modern thought, the modern arts, sound, and theories of ideology and subjectivity. Productive work in some modern medium or textual mode is encouraged for all concentrators. MCM’s approach to production recognizes the inextricable link between theory and practice, and the possibility of a fruitful complicity between them. Production, in the sense defined here, is a theoretically informed sphere or practice, one within which acknowledged forms of cultural creation are tested and extended in close complementarity with the analyses conducted elsewhere in MCM.</p>
<h2>College Writing Requirement</h2>
<p>MCM concentrators must complete the College Writing Requirement by taking two writing-intenstive or WRIT courses.</p>
<h2>11 Course Requirements:</h2>
<table>
<tbody>
<tr>
<td style="width:30%" scope="col"><strong>3 core courses</strong></td>
<td>
<p>a. MCM0150 <br />(MCM0150 replaced MCM0110.)<br /><span>Concentrators can substitute MCM0110 to fulfill the MCM0150 requirement.&nbsp;</span></p>
<p><br />b. two of the following core courses: MCM0220, MCM0230, MCM0240, MCM0250, MCM0260, MCM1110.<br /><br />No more than three courses from this list may count for concentration requirements.&nbsp;</p>
</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td><strong>5 courses, of which</strong></td>
<td>a. one must be an upper level course numbered MCM1200<br /><br />b. two must be senior seminars (MCM1500 or MCM1700)<br /><br />c. the remaining two must be at any level in MCM above MCM0260&nbsp;<br /></td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td><strong>3 additional courses</strong></td>
<td>These courses may be in MCM or in related departments. The specific courses must be approved by an MCM concentration advisor as part of a coherent program of study. <br /><br />T<span>rack I HONOR students may substitute MCM1970 <em>Directed Research: Modern Culture and Media </em>for one of these "3 additional courses."</span></td>
</tr>
</tbody>
</table>
<h2>Other Requirements:</h2>
<table>
<tbody>
<tr>
<td style="width:30%" scope="col"><strong>Focus Area</strong></td>
<td><span>Of the 11 courses required for the concentration, at least 3 courses must be in a focus area approved by a concentration advisor. These courses may be MCM courses, related courses, or a combination of the two, and they must represent a focus on some aspect of modern literature, theory, media, art or culture. Examples of possible focus areas are: mass/popular culture, gender/sexuality, language/ representation/subjectivity, narrative, digital media, film, modern thought, television, the modern arts, the novel, colonialism and post-colonialism. This is&nbsp;</span><strong>not</strong><span>&nbsp;an exhaustive list. Production courses may be in the focus area but must be in addition to the minimum 3 courses.</span></td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td><strong>Production</strong></td>
<td><span>Work in production is encouraged but not required for &nbsp;Track I concentrators. Of the 11 courses required for concentration, as many as 3 may be in production. These may be production courses offered by MCM (film, video, digital media) or courses in creative writing, painting, photography, journalism, etc., provided they do not bring the total number of concentration courses taken outside MCM to more than 3.</span></td>
</tr>
</tbody>
</table>
<h2>Double Concentrations:</h2>
<p><span>Students who declare a double concentration may count up to two courses for concentration credit in MCM that are also counted towards concentration credit in another department or program.</span></p>
<h2><span>H<span><span><span>onors:</span></span></span></span></h2>
<div class="gmail_default">
<p>Students who qualify for&nbsp;Honors&nbsp;in Track I are eligible to apply to do an&nbsp;Honors&nbsp;project or thesis. Students should submit a letter of intent in their 6<sup>th</sup>&nbsp;semester, and a formal proposal, by the first day of their 7<sup>th</sup>&nbsp;semester.&nbsp;&nbsp;Applications will be screened by the MCM&nbsp;Honors&nbsp;Committee. (Application forms are available in the MCM office.) If approved, a student must then register for MCM1970, a one credit course which can count towards their Focus Area requirements, and MCM1990, a one-credit thesis course in which they complete the&nbsp;Honors&nbsp;thesis.</p>
<div></div>
</div>
  </div>

	
  <div class="clear-block">
    <div class="meta">


	    
		</div><!-- end .meta -->
	</div>

</article>
 </div>

          <li><a href="http://instagram.com/brownu" title="Instagram" id="footer-instagram">Instagram</a></li>
          <li><a href="http://itunes.apple.com/institution/brown-university/id381076688#ls=1" title="iTunes U" id="footer-itunesu">iTunes U</a></li>
          <li><a href="https://plus.google.com/100931085598361161047/posts" title="Google+" id="footer-google-plus">Google+</a></li>
          <li><a href="https://www.linkedin.com/edu/school?id=19348&trk=tyah" title="LinkedIn" id="footer-linkedin">LinkedIn</a></li>
        <li><a href="https://www.snapchat.com/add/brown-u" title="brown-u on Snapchat" id="footer-snapchat">SnapChat</a></li>  
        </ul>
      </div>
    </div>

		<div class="content">



	<!--div id="node-1078" class="ultibanner banner"-->

          <div class="banner-text">
				<h1><a href="/academics/modern-culture-and-media/" title=""><span class="site-title"></span></a></h1><div id="site-mission" class="mission banner-subtext"></div>			</div>
        </section>
	  
  <!-- Layout -->
  <div id="content">
    <div class="marginator">
                  <div class="columns main-columns">
        <h1 class="article-title  with-tabs">Track I</h1>                        <div id="body-content" class="second-column column main-column">
                                                  <div class="clear-block"> 
<article id="node-189" class="main-article node">








  <div class="content">
        <p>Track I concentrators may choose to study a particular historical moment, a medium, or a mode of textual production, in combination with theoretical studies that examine the categories of cultural analysis: for example, the distinction between high and low culture. Examples of areas of interest include but are not limited to film, gender/sexuality, digital media, television, post-coloniality, the novel, modern thought, the modern arts, sound, and theories of ideology and subjectivity. Productive work in some modern medium or textual mode is encouraged for all concentrators. MCM’s approach to production recognizes the inextricable link between theory and practice, and the possibility of a fruitful complicity between them. Production, in the sense defined here, is a theoretically informed sphere or practice, one within which acknowledged forms of cultural creation are tested and extended in close complementarity with the analyses conducted elsewhere in MCM.</p>
<h2>College Writing Requirement</h2>
<p>MCM concentrators must complete the College Writing Requirement by taking two writing-intenstive or WRIT courses.</p>
<h2>11 Course Requirements:</h2>
<table>
<tbody>
<tr>
<td style="width:30%" scope="col"><strong>3 core courses</strong></td>
<td>
<p>a. MCM0150 <br />(MCM0150 replaced MCM0110.)<br /><span>Concentrators can substitute MCM0110 to fulfill the MCM0150 requirement.&nbsp;</span></p>
<p><br />b. two of the following core courses: MCM0220, MCM0230, MCM0240, MCM0250, MCM0260, MCM1110.<br /><br />No more than three courses from this list may count for concentration requirements.&nbsp;</p>
</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td><strong>5 courses, of which</strong></td>
<td>a. one must be an upper level course numbered MCM1200<br /><br />b. two must be senior seminars (MCM1500 or MCM1700)<br /><br />c. the remaining two must be at any level in MCM above MCM0260&nbsp;<br /></td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td><strong>3 additional courses</strong></td>
<td>These courses may be in MCM or in related departments. The specific courses must be approved by an MCM concentration advisor as part of a coherent program of study. <br /><br />T<span>rack I HONOR students may substitute MCM1970 <em>Directed Research: Modern Culture and Media </em>for one of these "3 additional courses."</span></td>
</tr>
</tbody>
</table>
<h2>Other Requirements:</h2>
<table>
<tbody>
<tr>
<td style="width:30%" scope="col"><strong>Focus Area</strong></td>
<td><span>Of the 11 courses required for the concentration, at least 3 courses must be in a focus area approved by a concentration advisor. These courses may be MCM courses, related courses, or a combination of the two, and they must represent a focus on some aspect of modern literature, theory, media, art or culture. Examples of possible focus areas are: mass/popular culture, gender/sexuality, language/ representation/subjectivity, narrative, digital media, film, modern thought, television, the modern arts, the novel, colonialism and post-colonialism. This is&nbsp;</span><strong>not</strong><span>&nbsp;an exhaustive list. Production courses may be in the focus area but must be in addition to the minimum 3 courses.</span></td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td><strong>Production</strong></td>
<td><span>Work in production is encouraged but not required for &nbsp;Track I concentrators. Of the 11 courses required for concentration, as many as 3 may be in production. These may be production courses offered by MCM (film, video, digital media) or courses in creative writing, painting, photography, journalism, etc., provided they do not bring the total number of concentration courses taken outside MCM to more than 3.</span></td>
</tr>
</tbody>
</table>
<h2>Double Concentrations:</h2>
<p><span>Students who declare a double concentration may count up to two courses for concentration credit in MCM that are also counted towards concentration credit in another department or program.</span></p>
<h2><span>H<span><span><span>onors:</span></span></span></span></h2>
<div class="gmail_default">
<p>Students who qualify for&nbsp;Honors&nbsp;in Track I are eligible to apply to do an&nbsp;Honors&nbsp;project or thesis. Students should submit a letter of intent in their 6<sup>th</sup>&nbsp;semester, and a formal proposal, by the first day of their 7<sup>th</sup>&nbsp;semester.&nbsp;&nbsp;Applications will be screened by the MCM&nbsp;Honors&nbsp;Committee. (Application forms are available in the MCM office.) If approved, a student must then register for MCM1970, a one credit course which can count towards their Focus Area requirements, and MCM1990, a one-credit thesis course in which they complete the&nbsp;Honors&nbsp;thesis.</p>
<div></div>
</div>
  </div>

	
  <div class="clear-block">
    <div class="meta">


	    
		</div><!-- end .meta -->
	</div>

</article>
 </div>

	<!--div id="node-1078" class="ultibanner banner"-->
		<img  class="imagefield imagefield-field_ultibanner_image" width="940" height="300" alt="" src="https://www.brown.edu/academics/modern-culture-and-media/sites/brown.edu.academics.modern-culture-and-media/files/ultibanner/ursa_minor_robust_banner_image.jpg?1467310782" />	<!--/div-->

          <div class="banner-text">
				<h1><a href="/academics/modern-culture-and-media/" title=""><span class="site-title"></span></a></h1><div id="site-mission" class="mission banner-subtext"></div>			</div>
        </section>
	  
  <!-- Layout -->
  <div id="content">
    <div class="marginator">
                  <div class="columns main-columns">
        <h1 class="article-title  with-tabs">Track II</h1>                        <div id="body-content" class="second-column column main-column">
                                                  <div class="clear-block"> 
<article id="node-190" class="main-article node">








  <div class="content">
        <p>The Track II concentration combines production courses with the critical study of the cultural role of practice. It aims to engage students in the analysis of theories of production elaborated within philosophical, artistic, and technological traditions, while encouraging them to produce works that interrogate these traditions.</p>
<h2>College Writing Requirement</h2>
<p>MCM concentartors must complete the College Writing Requirement by taking two writing-intenstive or WRIT courses.</p>
<h2>11 Course Requirements:</h2>
<table>
<tbody>
<tr>
<td><strong>2 core courses</strong> (chosen with the advisor to reflect the student’s production interest)&nbsp;</td>
<td>
<p>a. MCM0150<br /><span>(MCM0150 replaced MCM0110.)</span><br /><span>Concentrators can substitute MCM0110 to fulfill the MCM0150 requirement.&nbsp;</span></p>
<p>b. Introductory Practice Course&nbsp;(For example: MCM0710, MCM0730, MCM0750, VISA0100, VISA0110, VISA0120, MUSC0200, CSCI0150, LITR0110, LITR0210) or History of a Medium or Practice (for example: HIAA0010, TAPS0030, MUSC0010, or MUSC0040)&nbsp;</p>
</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td><strong>1 course</strong> from list</td>
<td><span>Students must complete at least one course from the following list: <br />MCM0220, MCM0230, MCM0240, MCM0250, MCM0260, MCM1110</span><br /></td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td><strong>3 courses </strong>numbered&nbsp;MCM1200 or MCM1500</td>
<td><span><span>At least one of these courses must be MCM1500.</span></span></td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td><strong>4 practic courses</strong></td>
<td>
<p>Practice courses must be selected in consultation with an advisor.&nbsp;Courses can be in any medium or combinatory sequence of media from the following departments: Modern Culture &amp; Media, Visual Art, Music, Literary Arts, Theatre and Performance Studies, Computer Science, Engineering, supplemented by approved courses at Rhode Island School of Design and study abroad. (This list is not exhaustive.)<br /><span></span></p>
<p><span>T</span><span>rack II HONOR students may substitute MCM1970&nbsp;<em>Directed Research: Modern Culture and Media&nbsp;</em>for one of these "4 practice courses."</span></p>
</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td><strong>1 senior seminar</strong></td>
<td><span>MCM1700 Seminars in Production or other equivalent in production.</span></td>
</tr>
</tbody>
</table>
<h2>Double Concentrations:</h2>
<p><span>Students who declare a double concentration may count up to two courses for concentration credit in MCM that are also counted towards concentration credit in another department or program.</span></p>
<h2>Honors: &nbsp;</h2>
<p><strong></strong><span>Students who qualify for&nbsp;</span><span class="il">Honors</span><span>&nbsp;in Track II are eligible to apply to do an&nbsp;</span><span class="il">Honors</span><span>&nbsp;project or thesis. Students should submit a letter of intent in their 6</span><sup>th</sup><span>&nbsp;semester, and a formal proposal, by the first day of their 7</span><sup>th</sup><span>&nbsp;semester.&nbsp; Applications will be screened by the MCM&nbsp;</span><span class="il">Honors</span><span>&nbsp;Committee. (Application forms are available in the MCM office.) If approved, a student must then register for MCM1970, a one credit course which can count towards their Focus Area requirements, and MCM1990, a one-credit thesis course in which they complete the&nbsp;</span><span class="il">Honors</span><span>&nbsp;project/thesis.&nbsp;</span></p>
  </div>

	
  <div class="clear-block">
    <div class="meta">


	    
		</div><!-- end .meta -->
	</div>

</article>
 </div>

<div class="street-address">155 George Street</div>
